title: Adjust header logo rendering for mobile menu and brand color

requirements.summary: Remove any logo rendering from the opened mobile navigation panel while keeping the header logo unchanged and clickable.
acceptanceCriteria: On mobile, opening the hamburger menu does not show any logo within the menu panel (no top bar logo, no duplicate logo).
The site header (top bar) still displays the logo and remains clickable to navigate to Home.
Desktop header continues to display the logo as before.

file_operations.description: Remove the mobile menu top section that renders the UtthanLogo inside the opened mobile navigation panel, and remove any now-unused mobile-logo click handler logic; keep the existing header <Link> logo unchanged so it remains clickable to Home.

requirements.summary: Recolor the header logo to exactly #70316c everywhere it appears in the header, while continuing to use the same /assets/logo.svg asset.
acceptanceCriteria: The rendered logo color in the header matches exactly #70316c (visually and via computed styles where applicable).
No other UI elements are unintentionally recolored when applying the logo color.
The logo continues to render as a graphic (not alt text) and uses the same logo.svg asset path consistently.

file_operations.description: Update UtthanLogo to render the existing /assets/logo.svg as a graphic with a fixed brand color of #70316c (e.g., via a dedicated logo styling approach that tints only the logo and does not affect other UI), ensuring the same asset path is used consistently.

Add a narrowly-scoped CSS utility/class (used only by UtthanLogo) that applies the #70316c color to the logo rendering while referencing the existing frontend/public assets path for logo.svg, ensuring no global element color rules are changed.

If the UtthanLogo implementation changes away from a plain , adjust the logo sizing classes passed in the header so the logo remains visually consistent across desktop header and mobile header top bar while keeping the logo color #70316c and avoiding layout redesign.
